importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Paris Climate Agreement, marking a turning point in global climate policy and emissions commitments.
The publication date of the climate study on superhot days, indicating the current state of climate change impacts and attribution.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2015 to 2100 reflects the impact of climate policy changes, especially post-Paris Agreement, on the number of superhot days.

keyTakeAways: The world will see an additional 57 superhot days annually by 2100 due to climate change, even under current emission reductions.
The Paris Climate Agreement reduced the projected warming from 4°C to 2.6°C, cutting the number of superhot days from 114 to 57.
Since 2015, the world has already added 11 superhot days on average.
Small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa will experience the largest increases in dangerous heat, with Panama projected to see 149 extra superhot days per year.
Top carbon-polluting countries (U.S., China, India) face only 23–30 extra superhot days despite being responsible for 42% of global CO₂ emissions.
The disparity in heat exposure reveals a profound climate injustice, with low-emitting, vulnerable nations suffering disproportionately.
Experts warn that such inequality could fuel geopolitical instability between rich and poor nations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central finds that climate change will add 57 superhot days per year by 2100, significantly less than the 114 predicted under a 4°C warming scenario, thanks to the Paris Climate Agreement. However, the world has already added 11 superhot days since 2015. The impact is highly uneven: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa will face massive spikes in dangerous heat—such as 149 extra days in Panama—while the top carbon emitters, including the U.S., China, and India, face only 23–30 extra days despite contributing 42% of global emissions. Experts warn that this disparity reflects deep climate injustice and could exacerbate global tensions between developed and developing nations.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
